article.title: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer membrane vesicle production of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri

funding.text: Florida Space Institute Space Research Initiative
NASA Florida Space Grant Consortium Scholarship
National Institutes of Health grant F32 GM119238

article.abstract: Reduced gravity, or microgravity, can have a pronounced impact on the physiology of animals, but the effects on their associated microbiomes are not well understood.

sections.introduction: All animals form beneficial associations with microbes, and these symbioses, collectively called the microbiome, constitute a powerful determinant of development, health, and fitness1,2.
sections.methods: The strains of V. fischeri used in this study include: wild-type V. fischeri ES11484; the non-motile, flagellated, mutant motB1::Tn7ermR; and the non-flagellated mutant flhA::Tn7ermR45.
sections.results: During exponential growth in the HARV reactors, V. fischeri cells released significantly more LPS under LSMMG conditions than gravity controls even after being normalized by optical density, an indicator of cell mass (Fig. 2a).
sections.discussion: Over the coming decade, human-led exploration of space will likely move beyond low Earth orbit into deeper space50.

article.insights_summary: This study found that modeled microgravity increases the shedding of bacterial LPS and associated OMVs into the surrounding media, and that flagellar motility in V. fischeri accounted for most of the overall OMV production, but was not necessary for increases in LPS shedding under LSMMG conditions.
